Sun of Faith - English: Chapter 15: The meditation in the countryside
After the excursion, the king interrogated Chandaka (Mdun pa) as he had done on previous occasions.
Manual - English: The Buddha goes to the fields where he sets free farmers and bulls. In another scene, he also sets free house servants. The Buddha goes to meditate in the shade under a rose apple tree (shing 'dzam bu) where his father prostrates him.

Sun of Faith - English: Later the king muttered to himself: “Well, this is most inconvenient! I shall send the prince to the countryside to divert him from such thoughts.”
“Siddhartha,” he declared, “I wish you to go to the village and monitor the progress of the tilling of the fields.”
Because of his recent encounters with the old man, the sick man and the dead man, the Bodhisattva's heart was in turmoil
and he had only one thing on his mind: the life of a renunciate.
But on hearing his father's commands, he climbed into his carriage and left for the farmers' hamlet.
All of a sudden, five hundred gemstone mines opened out in front of him while he was still en route,
and he heard a voice declare: “Prince, we are your ancestors' treasure trove, make of us what use you will.”
“I have no need of you,” the prince replied. “Out of my sight!
Those who speak to me of the dead come already as the harbingers of Death.
Soon, I too, scarcely cold, shall be but a tale recounted by others."
And the jewels disappeared to the bottom of the vast ocean.
Once he reached the village, the Bodhisattva watched the farm work being carried out.
He noticed the callused hands and feet of the peasants
and the exhausted oxen bleeding under their yoke.
An ineffable compassion filled his heart.
“Try, all of you, to be happy!” he implored,
as he released the laborers from their toil. Then he had the draught animals unharnessed.
The exchange with the poor peasants having served only to increase his distress, the prince went off to seek the quiet and shade of a grove.
Seating himself under a plum-rose tree, he spontaneously entered the first level of meditative concentration.
Scene working notes: The Vinayavastu source does characterize the meditation as "samadhi" (ting nge 'dzin): 'dod pa las dben pa sdig pa mi dge ba'i chos rnams las dben pa/_rtog pa dang bcas dpyod pa dang bcas shing dben pa las skyes pa'i dga' ba dang bde ba zag pa med pa dang 'dra ba'i bsam gtan dang po la snyoms par zhugs so/ (6b.4-5)

Sun of Faith - English: While he continued in the state of contemplative equanimity,
a large gathering of people who did not wish to separate themselves from the presence of the Bodhisattva, came to wait under the trees of the clearing.
“The prince has been away a long time,” fretted Shuddhodana.
“The hour for taking our midday meal has come and gone. We shall go and see what has become of him”.
He mounted his carriage and took the road to the village.
When the king approached the clearing where the Bodhisattva was, it was already past noon;
the shadows of the trees had started to lengthen eastward.
But the plum-rose tree's shadow, as if unwilling to be detached from the Bodhisattva (just like the cluster of people nearby), continued to cast itself directly vertically.
At this, feeling suddenly great respect, the king prostrated at the feet of his son, and paid tribute to him in the following words:
"At your birth, the very breast of the earth shuddered.
Now the shadow of a plum-rose tree refuses to be parted from you.
Great being, these are two miraculous foreshadowings.
All-knowing One, I touch the ground in homage to you."
He then pulled the prince away from his meditation
and both took their places in the carriage.
The road to the palace skirted a graveyard; here, heaps of bloated corpses could be seen.
Engulfed with sadness at this sight,
the Bodhisattva crossed his legs in the lotus position and fell to the carriage's floorboards,
again entering into the meditative state.
Scene working notes: Here, the Vinayavastu simply says that he "made a cross-legged posture" (skyil mo krung bcas pa) but does not mention meditation or samadhi (ting nge 'dzin) (7a.5)

Sun of Faith - English: Once more his father had to tear him away from his deep concentration.
Upon the return of father and son to Kapilavastu, the oracle priests warned:
“If in the course of this week, the prince does not renounce the world, he will become a universal monarch."
[The king] responded, "if that, indeed, is his desire,
keep him under strict surveillance for seven nights.
The parasol of the world's sovereigns will undoubtedly be seen floating above his head
and the seven precious attributes will certainly hover all round him.”
